text: Early Reading Strategies: Phonemic Awareness and Phonological Knowledge

children.text: Demonstrates phonemic awareness and applies phonological knowledge and skills by…
Blending and segmenting syllables and onset-rimes (e.g., cup-cake, s-at) (Local)
Isolating phonemes in single syllable words (e.g., Tell me the first sound in "mop;" tell me the last sound in "mop") (Local)
Recognizing pairs of rhyming words (Local)
Demonstrates phonemic awareness and applies phonological knowledge and skills by…
Blending and segmenting syllables and onset-rimes (e.g., cup-cake, s-at) (Local)
Blending and segmenting phonemes in one syllable words (e.g., f-i-sh, r-u-n) (Local)
Isolating phonemes in single syllable words (e.g., Tell me the first sound in "mop;" tell me the last sound in "mop;" tell me the middle sound in "mop" ) (Local)
Deleting phonemes in one-syllable words ("what is "crust" without the ‘c'?") (Local)
Producing pairs of rhyming words (Local)
Counting syllables in 1 to 4-syllable words (Local)
Demonstrates phonemic awareness and applies phonological knowledge and skills by…
Blending and segmenting phonemes in more complex one-syllable words (which may include combinations of blends and digraphs, as in th-i-ck, t-r-a-sh) (Local)

text: Early Reading Strategies: Concepts of Print

children.text: Demonstrates understanding of concepts of print during shared or individual reading by…
Distinguishing between printed letters and words (Local)
Following text with finger-pointing (e.g., charts, simple books), demonstrating left-to right and top-to bottom directionality (Local)
Identifying the first and last parts of a word (beginning/end of the word) (Local)
Identifying key parts of a book: front and back, print, illustrations (Local)
Demonstrates understanding of concepts of print during shared or individual reading by…
Identifying title, author, illustrator (Local)
Identifying basic punctuation marks and their usage (e.g., question marks, periods, quotation marks) (Local)
Demonstrating 1-1 matching of words spoken to words in print (Local)
Reads grade-level appropriate material with…
Accuracy: reading material appropriate for the end of grade 1 with at least 90-94% accuracy (Local)
Fluency: reading previously - introduced or previously read grade-appropriate text with oral fluency rates of at least 50-80 words correct per minute (Local)
Fluency: reading grade-appropriate text in a way that makes meaning clear, and demonstrates phrasing, expression, and attention to end punctuation (Local)
Reads grade-level appropriate material with…
Accuracy: reading material appropriate for the end of grade 2 with at least 90- 94% accuracy (Local)
Fluency: reading grade-appropriate text with oral fluency rates of at least 80-100 words correct per minute (Local)
Fluency: reading grade-appropriate text in a way that makes meaning clear, demonstrating phrasing, expression, and with attention to punctuation (including commas and quotation marks) (Local)
Reads grade-level appropriate material with…
Accuracy: reading material appropriate for grade 3 with at least 90-94% accuracy (Local)
Fluency: reading with oral fluency rates of at least 90- 120 words correct minute (Local)
Fluency: reading familiar text with phrasing and expression, and with attention to text features, such as punctuation, italics, and dialogue (Local)
Reads grade-level appropriate material with…
Accuracy: reading material appropriate for grade 4 with at least 90-94% accuracy (Local)

Fluency: reading with oral fluency rates of at least 115-140 words correct per minute (Students' rates of reading will and should vary in response to text difficulty, purpose of reading, and other factors.) (Local)
Fluency: reading familiar text with phrasing and expression, and with attention to text features, such as punctuation, italics, and dialogue (Local)
Reads grade-level appropriate material with…
Accuracy: reading material appropriate for grade 5 with 90-94% accuracy (Local)
Fluency: reading with appropriate silent and oral reading fluency rates as determined by text demands and purpose for reading (Local)
Fluency: reading familiar text with phrasing and expression, and with attention to text features, such as punctuation, italics, and dialogue (Local)

Demonstrating a basic understanding of how the letters of phonetically regular words (going from left to right), represent their sounds (Local)
Reading high frequency words, including names, environmental print, sight words (as appropriate to the child's personal and classroom experiences) (Local)
Recognizing and naming all upper and lower case letters (Local)
Identifying the primary sounds represented by most letters (sound-symbol correspondence) (Local)
Applies word identification and decoding strategies (leading to automaticity) by …
Sounding out regularly spelled (decodable) one-syllable or two-syllable words using letter-sound correspondence knowledge (Local)
Reading regularly spelled one or two-syllable words using knowledge of sounds and letter patterns (including common endings – s, ed, ly, ing) (Local)
Reading grade-level appropriate words (in connected text) (Local)
Reading grade- appropriate, high-frequency words (that include irregularly spelled words – said; contractions – I'm) (Local)

Identifying regularly spelled multi-syllabic words, by using knowledge of sounds, syllable types, or word patterns (including most common spellings for consonants and vowels, e.g., knot, catch, float, fight; or common suffixes) (State)

Using strategies to unlock meaning (e.g., activating prior knowledge, using cues, using context clues, or asking questions) (Local)

Shows breadth of vocabulary knowledge, demonstrating understanding of word meanings or relationships by …
Identifying synonyms and antonyms (e.g., big/large; hot/cold) to connect new words to known words (Local)
Demonstrating knowledge of basic concepts (i.e.: common words that describe position in space and time, such as: over, between, after, behind) (Local)
Organizing words by category (e.g., sorting pictures or objects into groups) (Local)

Identifying synonyms and antonyms to connect new words to known words (Local)
Selecting appropriate words to use in context (Local)
Describing words in terms of categories, (e.g., A mallard is a kind of duck.), functions (e.g., Scissors are used for cutting.), or features (e.g., A rectangle has four sides.) (Local)

Identifying synonyms or antonyms; or categorizing words (State)

text: Literary Texts: Initial Understanding of Literary Texts

children.text: Demonstrate initial understanding of elements of literary texts read aloud by…
Identifying characters in a story (Local)
Responding to simple questions about a book's content (e.g., What did that hungry caterpillar eat?) (Local)
Generating questions during read alouds (Local)
Demonstrate initial understanding of elements of literary texts (including text read aloud, reading independently, or in a guided manner) by…
Identifying characters or setting in a story (Local)
Responding to simple questions about a book's content (e.g., Where did Sylvester go?)
Retelling the beginning, middle, and end of a story (Local)
Generating questions before, during, and after reading (Local)
Distinguishing between literary and informational texts (Local)
Identifying literary devices as appropriate to genre: rhyme, repeated language (e.g., "teeny- tiny") (Local)
Demonstrate initial understanding of elements of literary texts by…
Identifying or describing character(s), setting, problem, solution, or major events, as appropriate to text (State)
Sequencing key events in order, as appropriate to text (Local)
Retelling the key elements of a story (Local)
Generating questions before, during, and after reading to enhance recall, expand understanding and/or gain new information (Local)
Distinguishing among a variety of types of text (e.g., literary texts: poetry, plays, realistic fiction, fairy tales, fables, tall tales, or fantasy) (Local)
Identifying literary devices as appropriate to genre: rhyme, repeated language or dialogue (e.g., "When I was young in the mountains…") (Local)
Demonstrate initial understanding of elements of literary texts by…
Identifying or describing character(s), setting, problem/solution, major events, or plot, as appropriate to text (State)
Paraphrasing or summarizing key ideas/plot, with events sequenced, as appropriate to text (State)
Generating questions before, during, and after reading to enhance recall, expand understanding and/or gain new information (Local)
Identifying the characteristics of a variety of types of text (e.g., literary texts: poetry, plays, fairytales, fantasy, fables, tall tales, or realistic fiction) (Local)
Identifying literary devices as appropriate to genre: rhyme, alliteration, dialogue, or description (Local)
Demonstrate initial understanding of elements of literary texts by…
Identifying or describing character(s), setting, problem/ solution, major events, or plot, as appropriate to text; or identifying any significant changes in character(s) over time (State)
Paraphrasing or summarizing key ideas/plot, with major events sequenced, as appropriate to text (State)
Generating questions before, during, and after reading to enhance recall, expand understanding and/or gain new information (Local)
Identifying the characteristics of a variety of types of text (e.g., literary texts: poetry, plays, fairytales, fantasy, fables, realistic fiction, folktales, historical fiction) (Local)
Identifying literary devices as appropriate to genre: rhyme, alliteration, simile, description, or dialogue (Local)
Demonstrate initial understanding of elements of literary texts by…
Identifying or describing character(s), setting, problem/solution, major events, or plot, as appropriate to text; or identifying any significant changes in character(s) over time (State)
Paraphrasing or summarizing key ideas/plot, with major events sequenced, as appropriate to text (State)
Generating questions before, during, and after reading to enhance recall, expand understanding and/or gain new information (Local)
Identifying the characteristics of a variety of types of text (e.g., literary texts: poetry, plays, fairytales, fantasy, fables, realistic fiction, folktales, historical fiction, mysteries) (Local)
Identifying literary devices as appropriate to genre: rhyme, alliteration, simile, dialogue, imagery, or simple metaphors (Local)
Demonstrate initial understanding of elements of literary texts by…
Identifying or describing character(s), setting, problem/solution, or plot, as appropriate to text; or identifying any significant changes in character or setting over time (State)
Paraphrasing or summarizing key ideas/plot, with major events sequenced, as appropriate to text (State)
Generating questions before, during, and after reading to enhance understanding and recall, expand understanding and/or gain new information (Local)

Identifying the characteristics of a variety of types/genres of literary text (e.g., literary texts: poetry, plays, fairytales, fantasy, fables, realistic fiction, folktales, historical fiction, mysteries, science fiction, myths, legends) (Local)
Identifying literary devices as appropriate to genre: rhyme, alliteration, simile, dialogue, imagery, simple metaphors, flashback, onomatopoeia, repetition, or idioms (Local)
Demonstrate initial understanding of elements of literary texts by…

Identifying or describing character(s), setting, problem/solution, or plot, as appropriate to text; or identifying any significant changes in character or setting over time; or identifying rising action, climax, or falling action (State)
Paraphrasing or summarizing key ideas/plot, with major events sequenced, as appropriate to text (State)
Generating questions before, during, and after reading to enhance/expand understanding and/or gain new information (Local)

Identifying the characteristics of a variety of types/genres of literary text (e.g., literary texts: poetry, plays, fairytales, fantasy, fables, realistic fiction, folktales, historical fiction, mysteries, science fiction, myths, legends, short stories) (Local)
Identifying literary devices as appropriate to genre: rhyme schemes, alliteration, simile, dialogue, imagery, metaphors, flashback, onomatopoeia, repetition, or personification (Local)
Demonstrate initial understanding of elements of literary texts by…

Identifying or describing character(s), setting, problem/solution, or plots/subplots, as appropriate to text; or identifying any significant changes in character or setting over time; or identifying rising action, climax, or falling action (Local)
Paraphrasing or summarizing key ideas/plot, with major events sequenced, as appropriate to text (Local)
Generating questions before, during, and after reading to enhance/expand understanding and/or gain new information (Local)

Identifying the characteristics of a variety of types/genres of literary text (e.g., literary texts: poetry, plays, fairytales, fantasy, fables, realistic fiction, folktales, historical fiction, mysteries, science fiction, myths, legends, short stories, epics, novels, dramas) (Local)
Identifying literary devices as appropriate to genre: rhyme schemes, alliteration, simile, dialogue, imagery, metaphors, flashback, onomatopoeia, repetition, personification, or hyperbole (Local)
Demonstrate initial understanding of elements of literary texts by…

Identifying, describing, or making logical predictions about character (such as protagonist or antagonist), setting, problem/solution, or plots/subplots, as appropriate to text; or identifying any significant changes in character, relationships, or setting over time; or identifying rising action, climax, or falling action (State)
Paraphrasing or summarizing key ideas/plot, with major events sequenced, as appropriate to text (State)
Generating questions before, during, and after reading to enhance/expand understanding and/or gain new information(Local)

Identifying the characteristics of a variety of types/genres of literary text (e.g., literary texts: poetry, plays, fairytales, fantasy, fables, realistic fiction, folktales, historical fiction, mysteries, science fiction, legends, myths, short stories, epics, novels, dramatic presentations, comedies, tragedies, satires, parodies, memoirs, epistles) (Local)

Identify literary devices as appropriate to genre (e.g., similes, metaphors, alliteration, rhyme scheme, onomatopoeia, imagery, repetition, flashback, foreshadowing, personification, hyperbole, symbolism, allusion, diction, syntax, bias, or point of view) (Local)
Demonstrate initial understanding of elements of literary texts by…

Identifying, describing, or making logical predictions about character (such as protagonist or antagonist), setting, problem/solution, or plots/subplots, as appropriate to text; or identifying any significant changes in character, relationships, or setting over time; or identifying rising action, climax, or falling action (Local)
Paraphrasing or summarizing key ideas/plot, with major events sequenced, as appropriate to text (Local)
Generating questions before, during, and after reading to enhance/expand understanding and/or gain new information (Local)

Identifying the characteristics of a variety of types/genres of literary text (e.g., literary texts: poetry, plays, fairytales, fantasy, fables, realistic fiction, folktales, historical fiction, mysteries, science fiction, legends, myths, short stories, epics, novels, dramatic presentations, comedies, tragedies, satires, parodies, memoirs, epistles) (Local)

Identify literary devices as appropriate to genre (e.g., similes, metaphors, alliteration, rhyme scheme, onomatopoeia, imagery, repetition, flashback, foreshadowing, personification, hyperbole, symbolism, allusion, diction, syntax, bias, or point of view) (Local)

text: Literary Texts: Analysis and Interpretation of Literary Text, Citing Evidence

children.text: Analyze and interpret elements of literary texts read aloud, citing evidence where appropriate by…
Making predictions about what might happen next (Local)
Identifying characteristics of main characters (Local)
Analyze and interpret elements of literary texts read aloud or read independently, citing evidence where appropriate by…
Making predictions about what might happen next, and telling why the prediction was made (Local)
Identifying physical characteristics, personality traits, or possible motives of main characters (Local)
Making basic inferences about the text (Local)
Analyze and interpret elements of literary texts, citing evidence where appropriate by…
Making logical predictions (State)
Identifying relevant physical characteristics or personality traits of main characters (State)
Making basic inferences about problem or solution (State)
Identifying the author's basic message (Local)
Identifying possible motives of main characters (Local)
Recognizing explicitly stated causes or effects (Local)
Analyze and interpret elements of literary texts, citing evidence where appropriate by…
Making logical predictions (State)
Describing main characters' physical characteristics or personality traits; or providing examples of thoughts, words or actions that reveal characters' personality traits (State)
Making basic inferences about problem, conflict, or solution (e.g., cause-effect relationships) (State)
Identifying who is telling the story (Local)
Identifying the author's basic message (State)
Identifying possible motives of characters (Local)
Recognizing explicitly stated causes or effects (Local)
Analyze and interpret author's craft, citing evidence where appropriate by…
Recognizing the use of literary elements and devices (i.e., imagery, exaggeration) to interpret intended meanings (Local)
Analyze and interpret elements of literary texts, citing evidence where appropriate by…
Making logical predictions (State)
Describing main characters' physical characteristics or personality traits; or providing examples of thoughts, words, or actions that reveal characters' personality traits (State)
Making inferences about problem, conflict, or solution (State)
Identifying who is telling the story (State)
Identifying author's message or theme (State)
Identifying causes or effects, including possible motives of characters (Local)
Analyze and interpret author's craft, citing evidence where appropriate by…
Demonstrating knowledge of use of literary elements and devices (i.e., imagery, exaggeration) to interpret intended meanings (Local)
Analyze and interpret elements of literary texts, citing evidence where appropriate by…
Making logical predictions (State)

Describing characters' physical characteristics, personality traits, or interactions; or providing examples of thoughts, words, or actions that reveal characters' personality traits or their changes over time (State)
Making inferences about problem, conflict, solution, or the relationship among elements (plot, character, setting) within text (e.g., how the setting affects a character or plot development) (State)
Identifying the narrator (State)
Identifying author's message or theme (implied or stated, as in a fable) (State)
Identifying causes or effects, including possible motives of characters (Local)
Analyze and interpret author's craft, citing evidence where appropriate by…
Demonstrating knowledge of use of literary elements and devices (i.e., imagery, exaggeration) to analyze literary works (State)
Analyze and interpret elements of literary texts, citing evidence where appropriate by…
Explaining or supporting logical predictions (e.g., providing evidence from text to explain why something is likely to happen next) (State)
Describing characters' traits, motivation, or interactions, citing thoughts, words, or actions that reveal characters' traits, motivations, or their changes over time (State)

Making inferences about cause/effect, external conflicts (e.g., person versus person, person versus nature/society/fate), or the relationship among elements within text (e.g., how the historical era influences the characters' actions or thinking) (State)
Explaining how the narrator's point of view affects the reader's interpretation (State)
Identifying author's message or theme (State)
Analyze and interpret author's craft, citing evidence where appropriate by…
Demonstrating knowledge of use of literary elements and devices (i.e., imagery, exaggeration, simile, metaphor, foreshadowing, or suspense) to analyze literary work (State)
Demonstrating knowledge of use of literary elements and devices (e.g., rhyme, alliteration, dialogue, flashback, onomatopoeia, repetition, or idioms) to analyze literary works (Local)
Analyze and interpret elements of literary texts, citing evidence where appropriate by…
Explaining or supporting logical predictions (State)
Describing characters' traits, motivation, or interactions, citing thoughts, words, or actions that reveal characters' traits, motivations, or their changes over time (State)

Making inferences about cause/effect (e.g., explaining how an event gives rise to the next), internal or external conflicts (e.g., person versus self, person versus person, person versus nature/society/fate), or the relationship among elements within text (State)
Explaining how the narrator's point of view affects the reader's interpretation (State)
Explaining how the author's message or theme is supported within the text (State)
Analyze and interpret author's craft, citing evidence where appropriate by…
Demonstrating knowledge of use of literary elements and devices (i.e., imagery, exaggeration, repetition, flashback, foreshadowing, or personification) to analyze literary works (State)
Demonstrating knowledge of use of literary elements and devices (e.g., rhyme schemes, alliteration, simile, dialogue, metaphors, onomatopoeia, repetition, or idioms) to analyze literary works (Local)
Analyze and interpret elements of literary texts, citing evidence where appropriate by…
Explaining or supporting logical predictions (Local)

Describing characterization (e.g., stereotype, antagonist, protagonist), motivation, or interactions, citing thoughts, words, or actions that reveal characters' traits, motivations, or their changes over time (Local)

Making inferences about cause/effect, internal or external conflicts (e.g., person versus self, person versus person, person versus nature/society/fate), or the relationship among elements within text (e.g., describing the interaction among plot/subplots) (Local)
Explaining how the narrator's point of view affects the reader's interpretation (Local)
Explaining how the author's message or theme (which may include universal themes) is supported within the text (Local)
Analyze and interpret author's craft, citing evidence where appropriate by…

Demonstrating knowledge of author's style or use of literary elements and devices (e.g., imagery, repetition, flashback, foreshadowing, personification, hyperbole, symbolism, or use of punctuation) to analyze literary works (Local)
Analyze and interpret elements of literary texts, citing evidence where appropriate by…
Explaining and supporting logical predictions or logical outcomes (e.g., drawing conclusions based on interactions between characters or evolving plot) (State)

Examining characterization (e.g., stereotype, antagonist, protagonist), motivation, or interactions (including relationships), citing thoughts, words, or actions that reveal character traits, motivations, or changes over time (State)

EXAMPLES of reading comprehension strategies might include: using prior knowledge; predicting and making simple text-based inferences; generating clarifying questions; constructing sensory images (e.g., making pictures in one's mind); or making connections (text to self, text to text, and text to world)
Uses comprehension strategies (flexibly and as needed) while reading or listening to literary and informational text. (Local)

EXAMPLES of reading comprehension strategies might include: using prior knowledge; predicting and making simple text-based inferences; generating clarifying questions; constructing sensory images (e.g., making pictures in one's mind); or making connections (text to self, text to text, and text to world)
Uses comprehension strategies (flexibly and as needed) while reading or listening to literary and informational text. (Local)

EXAMPLES of reading comprehension strategies might include: using prior knowledge; predicting and making text-based inferences; determining importance; generating literal and clarifying questions; constructing sensory images (e.g., making pictures in one's mind); or making connections (text to self, text to text, and text to world); or locating and using text features (e.g. headings, parts of the book)
Uses comprehension strategies (flexibly and as needed) before, during, and after reading literary and informational text. (Local)

EXAMPLES of reading comprehension strategies might include: using prior knowledge; predicting and making text-based inferences; determining importance; generating literal and clarifying questions; constructing sensory images (e.g., making pictures in one's mind); making connections (text to self, text to text, and text to world); or locating and using text features (e.g. transition words, subheadings, bold/italicized print, parts of the book)
Uses comprehension strategies (flexibly and as needed) before, during, and after reading literary and informational text. (Local)

EXAMPLES of reading comprehension strategies might include: using prior knowledge; sampling a page for readability; summarizing; predicting and making text-based inferences; determining importance; generating literal and clarifying questions; constructing sensory images (e.g., making pictures in one's mind); making connections (text to self, text to text, and text to world); locating and using text features (e.g. transition words, subheadings, bold/italicized print, parts of the book); or using text structure clues (e.g. chronological, cause/effect, compare/contrast, proposition and support, description, classification)
Uses comprehension strategies (flexibly and as needed) before, during, and after reading literary and informational text. (Local)

EXAMPLES of reading comprehension strategies might include: using prior knowledge; sampling a page for readability; summarizing; predicting and making text-based inferences; determining importance; generating literal, clarifying, and inferential questions; constructing sensory images (e.g., making pictures in one's mind); making connections (text to self, text to text, and text to world); taking notes; locating, using, and analyzing text features (e.g. transition words, subheadings, bold/italicized print, parts of the book); or using text structure clues (e.g. chronological, cause/effect, compare/contrast, proposition and support, description classification, and logical/ sequential)
